title: Flowery Heart
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
[My website: http://jlu227.wix.com/kay-lu
Hi visitors!
Since I am developing my website currently, I encourage you to visit my website and leave comments there! <3 :) ] Heart and flowers modeled in Mathematica separately, then using MeshMixer to edit, scale and put them together.
This is also a part for my 3D printing project "Surprise Box".
Update A
  • The original file named "Flowery_Heart_Right_Size_2" is the basic concept of it, and although it looks nice, it is not printable on most of the 3D printers, because of several problems, like too many shells, the petals are too thin, etc.
  • The printable and updated version is named "ReallyFinally3stl_repariedsimplied". This one has been cleaned, made solid, checked errors, strengthened and simplified. Therefore, this one is more suitable for printing. I will test it within a few days and put on the picture of the printed version here later.
    Also, since the original flowers were not suitable for printing, I changed the numbers of the formulas on Mathematica a little bit, and get some different shapes of flowers. (PS. If you notice, all the three flowers are different.) It is also interesting to discover that when I change the power of one of the formula, I will be able to generate something that looked like a butterfly! Therefore, I added the butterfly on the new version!
    Use for Cleaning and simplifying: MeshLab, NetFabb Basic.
    *Above software are all free.
    Update B
    Finally finished printing!
    I used the powdery SLS material to print it, and the machine used with this material also gave me the hollow effect inside the heart.
    :)
    I know that SLA should work too! But SLA may be more expensive and compared with SLS, it is more fragile. However, SLA could give you a more smooth surface.

comments.text: Were supports used in this and about how long did it take for you to print the final version?
comments.author: SnapCracklePrint

comments.text:
Hi,
Supports are not needed in this, because I used the Selective Laser Sintering machine in my university to print this, and it allows you to have a hollow effect inside.
comments.author: SnapCracklePrint

author: rickdegreef

description.text:
This is a lab probe that demands 2 extra thing, a spring and a paperclip.
In electronics you want to measure things and when you do that, you often have to hold other things... Here is a lab-probe "simple" one to make yourself!

This thing is based on 3 pcs, a mantle closes to you on the picture. A shield the middle part and last the lid. The lid is coded to fit into the shaft in only one way. To build this after printing you do the following. 1.) Straighten a paperclip and make a small loop on one end, solder a cable close to that loop and let the cable flow out of the slit in the hat.
2.) Secure the loop on the fastening hole you can see inside the hat
3.) Thread a spring from a pen or any old thing over the metal paperclip
4.) Place the mantle over the shaft
5.) Slit the paperclip thru the hole in the shaft so the spring works
6.) Glue the hat to the mantle
7.) Press the sliding mantle a bit down, while you bend the end of the paperclip tread to a loop you want. If everything is correct now, you should have a self holding retractable measure probe in your hands... Good luck

comments.text: Nice work. A picture with the assembled probe would really enlighten us how this probe is put together.

author: techedlamotte

description.text:
This is a Base for placing the Android Guy Box onto so it stands well.
The two small legs just do not provide a stable platform especially if you fill the inside of the Android Guy with something.
In order to fix this problem I created a base where the Android Guys feet fit into providing a stable platform.  He can still be removed from the base since it is not necessary to glue him to it.

• Print out 1 Head, 1 Body, 2 Arms, 2 Legs and 1 Base.
  • Glue arms into holes on side of body.
  • Glue legs into holes on bottom of body.
  • Place head on body as lid.
  • Place Android onto his base.
  • Enjoy.
    • I created the base by starting with the Android Guy Body, removing the hole making it solid and removing everything above the XY plane. This bottom of the body was then rotated 180 degrees around the X axis, a cylinder with a slant was added and the holes for the legs were made deeper.

title: Sony Alpha, NEX battery (NP-FW50) strap case

description.text:
Case for your spare Sony camera battery, NP-FW50 (or compatible). The battery easily slides into place and the case snaps it in place, and will hold it there until you pull it out. On the rear side it has a slot for attaching it to the camera strap so you always have it handy when needed. It can of course be used without a strap and will still protect the battery from bumps and scratches if you keep it in your pocket or bag. The case has a recession for the battery pins for maximum protection, which will offload any pressure put on the pins if dropped or hit. Fits batteries for the Sony Alpha A5000, A6000, NEX-3, NEX-5, NEX-6 and NEX-7 series cameras, or any other cameras that use the InfoLITHIUM W-series battery. v5 - UNTESTED
Stronger clips that holds the battery in place. Note that there has not been a single case reported of the battery falling out on v4, and the clips on v5 may prove too stiff, depending on the material of choice and infill settings.

Ready to be printed without support.  
Case in photo (v4) is printed in PLA, 0.1 layer height, then painted the Alpha logo with a gold felt pen. Note that I have some layer issues with my printer, the irregularities are from the printer, not the model.

comments.text: This is great, except the clips holding the battery in place are a bit to weak for my taste. I probably wouldn't wear this on my camera strap for risk of the battery falling out.
comments.author: bryanberger

comments.text:
Hi Bryan,
I have been using this for about 6 months now and the battery has not once fallen out by itself. I've just made and uploaded a new version just for you (v5) that has twice the thickness for the clips. Note that this is untested and it's possible that it makes it harder to get the battery in and out. If you do print it, please let me know how it works compared to the old one (v4).

This is a derivitive of my version 1 Raised J-Head mount, which was a derivative of roberlin's j-head mount: thingiverse.com/thing:53560.  
I raised the center portion to lift the hot end an additional 10mm so now the nozzle is approximately 8mm below the carriage (to allow clearance of the bolt head).  I could probably raise it a bit more to squeek out a little more Z height, but this is pretty darn close to max.  
I also made the inner mounting ring a little narrower to make it easier to mount the J-Head with a snug fit.  
The last improvement is the fan mount.  To make the motor sit better so the gear lines up better, I narrowed the top of the mount.  I wanted to reuse the "Front" part of the mount from my previous version without having to reprint it so to counter the offset for the fan screws, I made a custom shim.  Since I was making the new piece anyway, I added an air reflector to guide more air towards the J-Head.

Same as before:
  • Print this with at least 40% infill and use support for the serious overhangs
  • Drill or ream holes to fit
    • Hardware:
  • 2 x (20mm M5 bolt + nut + 2 washers) (I used nuts and bolts I had lying around that fit)
  • 2 x (16mm M3 machine screw)
  • 2 x (40mm M3 machine screws) these came with the qu-bd and are the right length for using their fan
  • 2 x (20mm M3 machine screw) for securing bdring's thing:38281 to the motor (I use mickb's thingiverse.com/thing:43411)
    • I uploaded files for extruding on the right side of the motor shaft. Mirror the pieces if you need the left side.

title: Removable Spool Arm for Lulzbot Mini 3D Printer

description.text:
This is a modification of the original Lulzbot Arm, to create a removable arm that slides into a bracket (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:756064) on the right side of the frame. This clears out the right side opening on the frame to allow for easy insertion of the panel for an enclosure (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:756211).
This mod simply cuts off the hinge portion of the stock arm, and tapers the end. As a side benefit the modified arm will print on the bed of the Lulzbot Mini, so you can use your printer to print your new arm. If anyone is interested in the laser cut part for a complete enclosure, I've put together a complete kit of the panels and assorted hardware to enclose the sides of your Lulzbot Mini printer.

title: T4 Quadcopter Arm with ESC cutout

description.text:
I modified the T4 Quadcopter arm to have a cutout for an ESC (DJI 30AMP). The arm also has holes cutout for zip ties to be put through the arm and around the ESC. I have also added another file for pancake motors. This file has the arm motor mount raised towards the top with a little space to recess the motor mount from the motor into the arm a little. The bottom is also cut out. I've also added a hole on the motor mount side of the arm to allow for a LED to be added. I've put my Rctimer 5010-620KV motors on this arm.
http://rctimer.com/product-911.html Tinker this at TinkerCAD:
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/eeyW3mPFbS7-t4-quadcopter-arm-esc

I printed this with ABS .2 25% Fill with supports using Davinci 1.0A.
Bed: 105
Extruder: 230 Since I was using ABS there is some shrinkage from the body, so I had to scale this model to 97.3% to fit in my body. This may not be an issue with others. Just something to keep in mind. I would print out a segment of the arm to test with your body before you commit with the full print.

author: helloboy

description.text:
V2 : Small improvements go a long way
Finally had time to finish modeling this project. Surprised at the amount of makes and I feel bad for you guys printing something that was incomplete. To make life easier, I updated 3 parts and added a new part to make the iris, but if you already printed the leafs, you can reuse them with the new parts. Hopefully this will give you guys a better table top piece to show off 3d printing. ORIGINAL POST V1
Saw a diy paper mechanical iris thing online and thought it was pretty cool. I couldn't find this style of iris on thingiverse, so I research different designs and found one that might be 3D printable on instructables. The trickiest part was getting the leafs printed thin enough plus have a pin on both sides. After a few leaf attempts I got it working fairly well, sadly It can not close all the way. Can't make the thing work any thinner then 0.6mm, maybe a different leaf design will allow it to close and probably use less leafs. This was really made as a 3D Printing Proof of concept. At some point down the line I might try to refine it by making some steam punk goggles, Also thinking of a possible camera lens cap that slides open and close when I need it without removing the cap. Inspired from Instructables Article :
http://www.instructables.com/id/How-to-make-a-12-leaves-Mechanical-Irirs/

Patreon - https://www.patreon.com/sketchpunk
Amazon Shop - http://astore.amazon.com/sketclabs-20

Need to print 11 leaf and pins. Glue the pins to the leafs so that there is a pin facing outward on each side. From there just use some clamp thing to help keep things together as you lay the leafs on the base.

title: Nautilus gears with involute herringbone gearing - customizable

description.text:
! be sure to have downloaded the newest version! this project continues my previous project (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:769012) which I published with an open callenge in mind. As it transfers the method I used there from 2D to 3D, I thought I'd besser set up the solution as a separate project. With ordinary fixed pitch gears, herringbone gearing is easily achieved by applying the powerful OpenSCAD primitive 'linear_extrude' with a 'twist' argument to a 2D object. When it comes to a more exotic pitch curve like an ellipse or the Nautilus spiral, this does not produce the desired result and the 'hard way' seems to be inevitable. So, what we do is: 'Roll a toothed herringbone rack along the raw Nautilus spiral object' this is my first print Notes:
  • to get a matching system herringbone direction must be mirrored (change sign of parameter s)
  • with the 3D method CGAL-rendering (F6) takes significantly longer (~30min)
  • click brackets in and glue them to any surface with gears aligned.
  • for further instructions and details please refer to
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:769012

comments.text: I'm having trouble getting these to work. They mesh perfectly, except for the transition to restart the spiral, where they lock up. I think there may be some relationship to the slope of the spiral and the depth of the teeth that's required to make this work. Any thoughts?
comments.author: tweinst

comments.text:
The transition is always a problem because the gear ratio changes abruptly at this point. Naturally downshift will cause less problems than upshifts. Also, not every possible parameterisation will produce a smooth transition, especially when large herringbone camfers and small teeth numbers are used. Additionally print quality will play some role and might demand some filing. As my prints came out well, watch my video, I didn't put further focus on that.
If is not print quality you could try to introduce some small offset shifting the rack a bit as it is moved along the spiral:

Tired of your phone running out of juice when you can't reach an outlet?  
Make yourself an emergency charger and bring that battery back to life!

Parts list: Lithium Ion Cylindrical Battery - 3.7V 2200mAh
https://www.adafruit.com/product/1781 Adafruit Mini Lipo w/Mini-B USB Jack - USB LiIon/LiPoly charger - v1
https://www.adafruit.com/product/1905 PowerBoost 500 Basic - 5V USB Boost @ 500mA from 1.8V+
https://www.adafruit.com/product/1903 Breadboard-friendly SPDT Slide Switch
https://www.adafruit.com/product/805 More information on my website here: http://dragonmountaindesign.com/2015/09/07/emergency-charger/

A gimbal designed for a small solar car being worked on by a few of my friends and I(Driftwood, TheGreenFilamet), to attach the panel to.  A bit stiff, but loosens quickly.  Do not worry if the fit takes some effort, and same to the tilting of the arms.
Just print and press fit!  If you scale the parts, scale them all the exact same amount.
External spool mount for flashforge dreamer printer.

This design uses a (1) 5-6" long 1/2"-13 bolt (vary length depending on spool size) and (1) 1/2"-13 nut inside the handle to hold the spool.  
Drill 1/2" hole in back plastic to feed bolt through the case.  I found flat bottom wood drill bit works best.  
Case mount uses (3) #6-32 2" long countersunk bolts and (3) standard hex nuts. I added aluminum stiffener washer in the photos, but my final design is a larger OD and does not need the stiffener.  
Match drill (3) #6 case mount holes by marking hole pattern from your printed parts.  
Handle uses (3) #6 1" lg countersunk screws  
The feed through uses a parker #111 O-ring (Mcmaster P/N: 9452K23) as the retention mechanism.  The design allows you to feed the existing teflon tubing through the part for a nice transition into the printer. A flat head screwdriver will help getting the o-rings onto the part.

title: Lulzbot TAZ 5 / 4 Low Friction Spool Holder Mount

description.text: So, I took a bit from both of these objects to build a rock solid mount for this awesome filament stand. Included are the STL's for the mount, clamps and a couple little spaces that I found that I needed at the bolt head, and between the spool holder and the mount that I put together. Used a 4" long 5/16" bolt to attach the spool holder to the mount, and four #6, 1" long screws to clamp the whole thing to the side of my TAZ 5. The back clamps are modified to have a little larger holes to accomodate the #6 screws. Get the rest of the pieces from here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:235925 This mount was made for the 608 bearing, so be sure to download the correct one. One thing to note, this low friction spool holder actually has such low friction, that the filament reel initially wanted to unspool itself due to the tension that the filament had from being put on the spool. This was remedied by adjusting the thickness of the spacer between the bearing and the TAZ5 frame mount against the bearings such that it drags a little against the frame side cone, thus preventing the spool from unwinding on it's own. Another issue that has been resolved is that because the spool sits a bit further out now, the feeder tube is too far in. Not an issue when the spool is half empty, but on full spools, it tends to want to pull the top row of filament off the spool. I've uploaded a couple different choices. One is simply a longer version than what comes with your TAZ. The other has a bit of a stop built in to prevent the filament tube holder from sliding inward. Both seem to work alright. I've switched to the one with the stop myself. Been using this setup on my printer for some time now and no complaints.

description.text:
Disclaimer: WARNING! Modifying electrics is dangerous! Do so at your own risk. I'm an idiot! So doing the things I do is not safe. PLEASE BE SAFE! This is how I modified a Hipro HP-W500FF3 Server Power Supply for use on my printer. This would also work for the Hipro HP-R650FF3 PS. Hipro HP-W500FF3 500W Server Power Supply
12v @ 41 Amps
5v @ 2 Amps This has a slot style connection. With the Hipro label up, and facing the fan the top of the connector left to right under the fan. ^ ^ ^ ^ ^ ^ |----------| |----------|
1 2 3 4 5 6 Gnd. 12V 3 Ps_On
4 Ps_Kill
6 5vsb Bottom side of the blade two larger pads are Gnd and 12v again Remove the 5 screws shown
And open the case to make it easier to solder wires.
Pull the case up, and connect wires on the correct pads. To turn on the power supply connect both Ps_On and Ps_Kill to Gnd. You could connect a on/off switch between PS_On and Gnd, and a
Emergency Kill button between PS_Kill and Gnd. I've made a cover to attach to a 20x40 extrusion for my printer.
I included the Openscad files so you can edit it for what you need.

And open the case to make it easier to solder wires.

comments.text:
Thanks for the information! I found a cheap HP-R650-FF3 and have been using it to power the heated bed on my 3d printer.
One question for you: when I turn the power supply off by disconnecting PS_ON_CTL (while leaving PS_KILL grounded), the fan on the power supply seems to spin up to maximum speed, which is quite loud and annoying. Did you have this problem? The power supply is actually much quieter when on (PS_ON_CTL and PS_KILL grounded). Any idea how to quiet the fan while the power supply is in shutdown?

This is a customizable dog tag. Not much to it.  
Its dimensions are 50 mm x 20mm x 4mm.

Just open the file in Thingiverse customizer and type in a name of 4 characters or less.

This was designed to be a simple solution to being away from loved ones, I figured that I could print a miniature version of myself for family and friends to facetime/skype on. I will be uploading a more generic version that doesn't have cowboy boots on. If you guys have any suggestions on improvement just leave me a comment.

This was made on an ultimaker 2 using 1.2 wall thickness and 20% infill. the piece in the phone holder (head) is designed to be removed, it was designed to help with the overhang. The part must be re-orientated to lay on its back. there really isn't a wrong way to print this.

I got up quickly from the toilet kicking the heater knob right off. Broke it in several places. Printed out a replacement knob. Probably fits most notched circle dials on household potentiometers.
I would like to add that you'll need to print this thing with support turned on.

comments.text: Hi Bluesmurf. So what you were experiencing was the printer trying to print onto thin air! 3d printers can't do that yet so what we do is build up support to the overhang, and then print onto the support. When it's all finished, you rip the support off and you have your piece! How do you add support you ask? There is a setting for it in your slicer. You'll most likely just need to check it on and it will add support to your gcode. Give it a go! I would be honored to have my thing be your first "supported" print. :)

title: Case for Raspberry Pi with Adafruit LCD display

description.text:
Based on Anoved's revision of Jeremy Blum's nice design, with the following updates:
  • Right side finger bevel for easier access to right button (watch Jeremy's Blum's Youtube vid).
  • closed a gap for the 2 halves near the 2 circular connectors
  • adjusted the HDMI bevels
  • tighter fit for the LCD from above (photo below still shows a small gap; the .stl file is 2 mm smaller on the right)
  • button opening smaller, now covering the IC and protecting the contrast pot some.
The 2 halves are not fastened strongly together; just the case friction and the LCD pins.  Use tape for more holding power.  Screw holes and bosses would require a larger overall case size.

author: Koderiter

description.text: These are the full STLs for the Piccolino micro-controller (on kickstarter April 15 - May 15). Releases as Open source (non-commercial) so feel free to modify and print as many as you want ! Make sure you rotate the back of the case 180 degrees so that it's flat with the tabs facing upwards. The main case is correct and will give you a nice glossy finish at the front (if you print on Kapton tape) If you're like us and like to mess and create cool things, check us out on kickstarter and see what this thing can do. It has WIFI + OLED + SD CARD + 32K SPI RAM + TOUCH on the bezel and it's of course fully Hardware Open Source ... https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/piccolino/piccolino-arduino-compatible-wifi-oled-sram-sd-car This page will keep being update with more enclosures and add-on so bookmark it. April 24th: Added finger space for SD card slot.
You can print this without any supports, which should work for just about any 3D printer. The case is dense enough to be printer in PLA or ABS.

description.text: UPDATE: Added a 9 volt battery clip that bolts to exhaust side of fan on either the side or the lowest side of the wedge. Can print one for each side for 18v configuration. Remove your solder fumes with this compact wedge that mates up to any standard 80mm fan. Power it with a 9 volt battery, or your own source. The optional top half allows you to position the extractor in even more positions, or allows you to attach a power source with the 4.5mm screw holes spaced 35.75mm apart. The design can be printed on a 4x4 print bed, and fans can be stacked or chained together .

author: Koderiter

description.text:
If you're like me and wear level your filament (I have a bunch of almost empty spools that I want to keep around so I have a decent color selection), you may find this useful.  It lets you put two colors on one spool (or more if you resize the divider and add more than one).  
I'd recommend printing just the top centimeter or so to do a test fit before trying to print the whole thing.  
There are two versions, sized for spools from Intservo/eSun and Monoprice (these are assembled with screws and are easy to take apart).

Here is a morse key I made. It has holes in it for feeding 22# wire through. I used maget wire 22# for this and works great. Also uses a gumband for the spring action. Must print the KEY with support.  
I used hot glue to hold it down to my table. You may be able to use tape or bubble sided tape.  
I added a .05mm offset KEYER so there will be less travel for the keyer for faster CW sending.

1.) Print the parts.
2.) Put the Key on the base.
3.) Feed the 2 Wires through the holes.
4.) Add the gumband.
5.) feed the base wire from one side RIGHT to LEFT and hot glue it down on the left side.
6.) bend down the KEY wire on the KEY. Left 3mm of wire after bending.
7.) strip the wire where it makes contact with a razer blade.
8.) Hot glue the KEY wire at the back.
9.) Connect to Radio with a 3.5mm jack and have fun.
